title: How to Make Halloween Sugar Cookies

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 375° Fahrenheit (190° Celsius).
steps.description: Grease a cookie tray with non-stick greasing spray.

steps.headline: Cream the butter and sugar.
steps.description: In a large bowl, cream the butter and sugar with an electric or hand blender until the mixture is light and fluffy.

steps.headline: Crack in the egg and add the vanilla extract into the creamed butter.
steps.description: Blend until well-combined and there are no more egg streaks.

steps.headline: Add the all-purpose flour, baking soda, and baking powder into the creamed mixture.
steps.description: Blend on low speed for about two minutes until the cookie dough starts to form. If the cookie dough is too dry, add 1-2 tablespoons of milk.

steps.headline: Chill the dough.
steps.description: Using your hands, roll the cookie dough into a large ball or roll it into two medium-sized balls. Place the cookie dough in a separate bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Place it in the fridge to chill for about an hour.

steps.headline: Roll out the dough.
steps.description: Remove the cookie dough from the fridge. Flatten the cookie dough ball by pressing your hands on it. Use a rolling pin to roll it out into a large rectangular shape.

steps.headline: Cut out pumpkin shapes from the dough with a pumpkin-shaped cookie cutter.
steps.description: Gently press the cookie cutter on the dough to cut each cookie.

steps.headline: Lay the cookies on the cookie tray using a spatula.
steps.description: Leave a two inch space between each cookie to avoid them from binding together when they bake.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies.
steps.description: Place the cookie tray in the oven. Have the cookies bake for about 8-10 minutes, until the edges are golden brown.

steps.headline: Let the cookies cool.
steps.description: Remove the cookie tray from the oven. Lay the cookies on a wire rack by removing them with a spatula. Have the cookies cool for about ten minutes

steps.headline: Prepare the frosting.
steps.description: Split the frosting into two bowls, each bowl with ½ cup of frosting. Add ten drops of food coloring into one the bowls and seven drops of green food coloring to the other bow. Stir until the colors are vibrant and is a vivid orange and green color. Place the green frosting in a frosting pipe.

steps.headline: Frost the cookies.
steps.description: Using a butter knife, spread orange frosting over the sugar cookies. Smooth out the frosting by gently smothering the butter knife around. Frost the 'stems' of the pumpkin by using the frosting pipe. Add a few curly green lines near the top of the sugar cookie. Repeat with all the cookies.

steps.headline: Serve the cookies on a serving plate with a glass of milk.
steps.description: Enjoy!

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 375° Fahrenheit (190° Celsius).
steps.description: Grease a cookie tray with non-stick greasing spray.

steps.headline: Cream the butter and sugar.
steps.description: In a large bowl cream the butter and sugar with an electric or hand blender until the mixture is light and fluffy.

steps.headline: Crack in the egg and add the vanilla extract into the creamed butter.
steps.description: Blend until well-combined and there are no more egg streaks.

steps.headline: Add the all-purpose flour, baking soda, and baking powder into the creamed mixture.
steps.description: Blend on low speed for about two minutes until the cookie dough starts to form. If the cookie dough is too dry, add 1-2 tablespoons of milk.

steps.headline: Chill the dough.
steps.description: Using your hands, roll the cookie dough into a large ball or roll it into two medium-sized balls. Place the cookie dough in a separate bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Place it in the fridge to chill for about an hour.

steps.headline: Roll out the dough.
steps.description: Remove the cookie dough from the fridge. Flatten the cookie dough ball by pressing your hands on it. Use a rolling pin to roll it out into a large rectangular shape.

steps.headline: Cut out cat shapes from the dough using a cat-shaped cookie cutter.
steps.description: Gently press the cookie cutter on the dough to cut each cookie.

steps.headline: Lay the cookies on the cookie tray using a spatula.
steps.description: Leave a two inch space between each cookie to avoid them from binding together when they bake.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies.
steps.description: Place the cookie tray in the oven. Have the cookies bake for about 8-10 minutes, until the edges are golden brown.

steps.headline: Let the cookies cool.
steps.description: Remove the cookie tray from the oven. Lay the cookies on a wire rack by removing them with a spatula. Have the cookies cool for about ten minutes.

steps.headline: Make the 'eyes' and 'whiskers'.
steps.description: Roll out the yellow fondant and cut out small circles to resemble the 'eyes'. Make the 'whiskers' by rolling out the white fondant and cutting small string-sized pieces.

steps.headline: Frost and decorate the cookies.
steps.description: Using a butter knife, spread black frosting over the sugar cookies. Smooth out the frosting by gently smothering the butter knife around. Add the two yellow pieces to resemble the eyes and add the 'whiskers' near the ends of the cookie. Repeat with all the cookies.

steps.headline: Serve the cookies on a serving plate with a glass of milk.
steps.description: Enjoy!

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 375° Fahrenheit (190° Celsius).
steps.description: Grease a cookie tray with non-stick greasing spray.

steps.headline: Cream the butter and sugar.
steps.description: In a large bowl cream the butter and sugar with an electric or hand blender until the mixture is light and fluffy.

steps.headline: Crack in the egg and add the vanilla extract into the creamed butter.
steps.description: Blend until well-combined and there are no more egg streaks.

steps.headline: Add the all-purpose flour, baking soda, and baking powder into the creamed mixture.
steps.description: Blend on low speed for about two minutes until the cookie dough starts to form. If the cookie dough is too dry, add 1-2 tablespoons of milk.

steps.headline: Chill the dough.
steps.description: Using your hands, roll the cookie dough into a large ball or roll it into two medium-sized balls. Place the cookie dough in a separate bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Place it in the fridge to chill for about an hour.

steps.headline: Roll out the dough.
steps.description: Remove the cookie dough from the fridge. Flatten the cookie dough ball by pressing your hands on it. Use a rolling pin to roll it out into a large rectangular shape.

steps.headline: Cut out skull shapes from the dough using a skull-shaped cookie cutter.
steps.description: Gently press the cookie cutter on the dough to cut each cookie.

steps.headline: Lay the cookies on the cookie tray using a spatula.
steps.description: Leave a two inch space between each cookie to avoid them from binding together when they bake.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies.
steps.description: Place the cookie tray in the oven. Have the cookies bake for about 8-10 minutes, until the edges are golden brown.

steps.headline: Let the cookies cool.
steps.description: Remove the cookie tray from the oven. Lay the cookies on a wire rack by removing them with a spatula. Have the cookies cool for about ten minutes.

steps.headline: Frost the cookies.
steps.description: Using a butter knife, spread white frosting over the sugar cookies. Smooth out the frosting by gently smothering the butter knife around. Pipe out the black frosting on the edges of the cookies. Frost two black circles on the 'skulls' and fill them in with black frosting to make the 'eyes'. Make the 'mouth' near the bottom of the eyes by forming a line and frosting tiny lines on it. Make the 'nostrils' by using the black frosting to make two ovals, right in the middle of the eyes and mouth.

steps.headline: Serve the cookies on a serving plate with a glass of milk.
steps.description: Enjoy!

steps.description: Blend until well-combined and there are no more egg streaks.

text: Pumpkin-Shaped Cookies Preheat the oven to 375° Fahrenheit (190° Celsius). Grease a cookie tray with non-stick greasing spray. Cream the butter and sugar. In a large bowl, cream the butter and sugar with an electric or hand blender until the mixture is light and fluffy. Crack in the egg and add the vanilla extract into the creamed butter. Blend until well-combined and there are no more egg streaks. Add the all-purpose flour, baking soda, and baking powder into the creamed mixture. Blend on low speed for about two minutes until the cookie dough starts to form. If the cookie dough is too dry, add 1-2 tablespoons of milk. Chill the dough. Using your hands, roll the cookie dough into a large ball or roll it into two medium-sized balls. Place the cookie dough in a separate bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Place it in the fridge to chill for about an hour. Roll out the dough. Remove the cookie dough from the fridge. Flatten the cookie dough ball by pressing your hands on it. Use a rolling pin to roll it out into a large rectangular shape. Cut out pumpkin shapes from the dough with a pumpkin-shaped cookie cutter. Gently press the cookie cutter on the dough to cut each cookie. Lay the cookies on the cookie tray using a spatula. Leave a two inch space between each cookie to avoid them from binding together when they bake. Bake the cookies. Place the cookie tray in the oven. Have the cookies bake for about 8-10 minutes, until the edges are golden brown. Let the cookies cool. Remove the cookie tray from the oven. Lay the cookies on a wire rack by removing them with a spatula. Have the cookies cool for about ten minutes Prepare the frosting. Split the frosting into two bowls, each bowl with ½ cup of frosting. Add ten drops of food coloring into one the bowls and seven drops of green food coloring to the other bow. Stir until the colors are vibrant and is a vivid orange and green color. Place the green frosting in a frosting pipe. Frost the cookies. Using a butter knife, spread orange frosting over the sugar cookies. Smooth out the frosting by gently smothering the butter knife around. Frost the 'stems' of the pumpkin by using the frosting pipe. Add a few curly green lines near the top of the sugar cookie. Repeat with all the cookies. Serve the cookies on a serving plate with a glass of milk. Enjoy! Black Cat Cookies Preheat the oven to 375° Fahrenheit (190° Celsius). Grease a cookie tray with non-stick greasing spray. Cream the butter and sugar. In a large bowl cream the butter and sugar with an electric or hand blender until the mixture is light and fluffy. Crack in the egg and add the vanilla extract into the creamed butter. Blend until well-combined and there are no more egg streaks. Add the all-purpose flour, baking soda, and baking powder into the creamed mixture. Blend on low speed for about two minutes until the cookie dough starts to form. If the cookie dough is too dry, add 1-2 tablespoons of milk. Chill the dough. Using your hands, roll the cookie dough into a large ball or roll it into two medium-sized balls. Place the cookie dough in a separate bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Place it in the fridge to chill for about an hour. Roll out the dough. Remove the cookie dough from the fridge. Flatten the cookie dough ball by pressing your hands on it. Use a rolling pin to roll it out into a large rectangular shape. Cut out cat shapes from the dough using a cat-shaped cookie cutter. Gently press the cookie cutter on the dough to cut each cookie. Lay the cookies on the cookie tray using a spatula. Leave a two inch space between each cookie to avoid them from binding together when they bake. Bake the cookies. Place the cookie tray in the oven. Have the cookies bake for about 8-10 minutes, until the edges are golden brown. Let the cookies cool. Remove the cookie tray from the oven. Lay the cookies on a wire rack by removing them with a spatula. Have the cookies cool for about ten minutes. Make the 'eyes' and 'whiskers'. Roll out the yellow fondant and cut out small circles to resemble the 'eyes'. Make the 'whiskers' by rolling out the white fondant and cutting small string-sized pieces. Frost and decorate the cookies. Using a butter knife, spread black frosting over the sugar cookies. Smooth out the frosting by gently smothering the butter knife around. Add the two yellow pieces to resemble the eyes and add the 'whiskers' near the ends of the cookie. Repeat with all the cookies. Serve the cookies on a serving plate with a glass of milk. Enjoy! Using your hands, roll the cookie dough into a large ball or roll it into two medium-sized balls. Place the cookie dough in a separate bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Smooth out the frosting by gently smothering the butter knife around. Pipe out the black frosting on the edges of the cookies. Frost two black circles on the 'skulls' and fill them in with black frosting to make the 'eyes'. Make the 'mouth' near the bottom of the eyes by forming a line and frosting tiny lines on it. Make the 'nostrils' by using the black frosting to make two ovals, right in the middle of the eyes and mouth. Serve the cookies on a serving plate with a glass of milk. Enjoy! Ghost Cookies Preheat the oven to 375° Fahrenheit (190° Celsius). Grease a cookie tray with non-stick greasing spray. Cream the butter and sugar. In a large bowl cream the butter and sugar with an electric or hand blender until the mixture is light and fluffy. Crack in the egg and add the vanilla extract into the creamed butter. Blend until well-combined and there are no more egg streaks. Add the all-purpose flour, baking soda, and baking powder into the creamed mixture. Blend on low speed for about two minutes until the cookie dough starts to form. If the cookie dough is too dry, add 1-2 tablespoons of milk. Chill the dough. Using your hands, roll the cookie dough into a large ball or roll it into two medium-sized balls. Place the cookie dough in a separate bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Place it in the fridge to chill for about an hour. Roll out the dough. Remove the cookie dough from the fridge. Flatten the cookie dough ball by pressing your hands on it. Use a rolling pin to roll it out into a large rectangular shape. Cut out ghost shapes from the dough using a ghost-shaped cookie cutter. Gently press the cookie cutter on the dough to cut each cookie. Lay the cookies on the cookie tray using a spatula. Leave a two inch space between each cookie to avoid them from binding together when they bake. Bake the cookies. Place the cookie tray in the oven. Have the cookies bake for about 8-10 minutes, until the edges are golden brown. Let the cookies cool. Remove the cookie tray from the oven. Lay the cookies on a wire rack by removing them with a spatula. Have the cookies cool for about ten minutes. Frost the cookies. Using a butter knife, spread white frosting over the sugar cookies. Smooth out the frosting by gently smothering the butter knife around. Pipe two small black dots with the black frosting to make the 'eyes'. Pipe a small black 'mouth' in the middle of the ghost. Repeat with all the cookies. Serve the cookies on a serving plate with a glass of milk. Enjoy! Bat Cookies Preheat the oven to 375° Fahrenheit (190° Celsius). Grease a cookie tray with non-stick greasing spray. Cream the butter and sugar. In a large bowl cream the butter and sugar with an electric or hand blender until the mixture is light and fluffy. Crack in the egg and add the vanilla extract into the creamed butter. Blend until well-combined and there are no more egg streaks. Add the all-purpose flour, baking soda, and baking powder into the creamed mixture. Blend on low speed for about two minutes until the cookie dough starts to form. If the cookie dough is too dry, add 1-2 tablespoons of milk. Chill the dough. Using your hands, roll the cookie dough into a large ball or roll it into two medium-sized balls. Place the cookie dough in a separate bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Place it in the fridge to chill for about an hour. Roll out the dough. Remove the cookie dough from the fridge. Flatten the cookie dough ball by pressing your hands on it. Use a rolling pin to roll it out into a large rectangular shape. Cut out bat shapes from the dough using a bat-shaped cookie cutter. Gently press the cookie cutter on the dough to cut each cookie. Lay the cookies on the cookie tray using a spatula. Leave a two inch space between each cookie to avoid them from binding together when they bake. Bake the cookies. Place the cookie tray in the oven. Have the cookies bake for about 8-10 minutes, until the edges are golden brown. Let the cookies cool. Remove the cookie tray from the oven. Lay the cookies on a wire rack by removing them with a spatula. Have the cookies cool for about ten minutes. Frost the cookies. Using a butter knife, spread black frosting over the sugar cookies. Smooth out the frosting by gently smothering the butter knife around. Cut a small piece of grey fondant and form it into a line to make the 'mouth'. Pipe two triangles near the mouth to make the 'teeth'. Pipe the eyes near the top with the white frosting. Make the 'wings' more realistic by rolling small pieces of the grey fondant and adding it on the wings. Serve the cookies on a serving plate with a glass of milk. Enjoy!
